Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: After taking calc in high school, this class definitely helped me touch back upon each topic and develop a better understanding of calc and its importance.
Not much new, a majority of this course was covered in AP Calculus AB, Newton's Method was new, however.
I developed knowledge of calculus and new mathematic components
This course really built upon the calculus that I learned in high school and now I understand the real meaning behind everything that we do in calculus.
This course refreshed me of my high school calculus knowledge and introduced a few new concepts.
I learned the fundamental theorems and properties of calculus. I gained a better understanding of calculus concepts such as Riemann sums.
In depth knowledge on limits, derivatives, and basic integrals.
I learned how to do calculus in a fast paced and timely manner
Differentiating and integrating
I gained a much more in depth understanding of the fundamentals of calculus.
A weakness of this class was that when we had a wed assign due the material of those questions was not covered until after it was due which made it very difficult to understand the questions.
The strengths of this course are the ways the course were taught but the weaknesses were the professors way of prepping us for the exams

I felt like the practice exams did not properly prepare us for the exams. The practice exams for both midterms had me believing that the test was going to be a nightmare when in actuality they were manageable, and the practice exams for the final exam did in no way prepare me for the difficulty level of the final. However, I found that the class itself really helped clarify things that I had read in the text and was imperative to my learning(students - this is why you should actually show up to class!).
It was well organized, but the exams were more difficult than the information presented in class and on the homework.

Strength:
1) It had an interesting professor who made the class fun sometimes
Weaknesses:
1) The questions on the problem sets were much more difficult than content covered during class.
2) if you werent familiar with calculus beforehand the class would be way too fast and not thorough enough to understand the concepts.

Strengths: the course moved at a good pace, and everything we learned ties into itself very nicely.
Weaknesses: Psets were harder than they needed to be, and I think at times there was more focus on algebraic manipulation than actual calculus concepts.
strengths were the tutors and availability of extra help in office hours, weakness was the way the questions were formatted on the tests were unlike the questions we had previously been exposed to
If you get a good instructor, this course can be a great way to learn the basics of calculus. The course is difficult though because it is a lot of work.
This course could have been better structured and I feel that sometimes the WebAssign and problem sets do not completely align with the material being taught in class.
Yes, because I feel like it left me with a good understanding of calc that will help me in the future.
Yes because it challenges you intellectually to be a better student

I would recommend this course to anyone who is on the fence about taking either this or MATH 115. High school calculus would not have prepared me for MATH 115, and in this course, I was able to build upon my calculus skills quite well.
Unless this student is strong in calculus, I would advise to take a lower level course. I did not take any form of AP calculus in high school, and I struggled in this class.
Yes, the workload was definitely manageable and it is a good class to take to reinforce content learned during high school calculus especially if it has been some time since youve last studied it.
Yes - calculus is an important subject for everyone to have a background in, and this class emphasizes the practical applications it has.
if it is required for your major then take it but if not then there is no need to stress about the class unless you need the credit
I would take this course if you need it, but beware that it is a lot of work and if you end up with a bad instructor is absolutely miserable.
Yes great math course
Yes, Fundamentals of Calculus are so important to learn as you go through and explore different STEM courses at Yale.
Yes, It is a good course to build a strong foundations of understanding for calculus
